bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, January 3, 1922

div1.p: Noguchi sends Carter eight ampoules of yellow fever vaccine and directions for its use.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, January 3, 1922
div1.opener:
Noguchi
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
January 3, 1922
Dear General Carter:
div1.p:
I am sending you by special delivery a package containing
eight ampoules of icteroides vaccine for your use. I send more than
you asked for because you may be able to keep the rest in the ice-box
in case you should have need for some in a short time. I will, of course,
be glad to send you a fresh supply any time you write me. I wish to
emphasize the importance of the fact that the second injection of vaccine
should be given within six days after the first. If by any chance more
than six days should pass, the injection should be disregarded and a
new first injection should be made, this time followed within six days
by the second one. I wish you would tell Mr. Ricketson not to go into
any infected district until at least ten days have elapsed since the last
injection. And, of course, as you know, he should be told that every
known precaution should be taken to prevent his being exposed to the
disease -- mosquito nets, etc., as usual -- as though he had had no
vaccination.
I am sending the material to you for Mr. Ricketson.

I reciprocate your good wishes for the new year, and am hoping
that you are in the best of health.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Hideyo Noguchi Asst. Surgeon General
Henry R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
2121 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
